newsitem.title: USA: Republicans big donors meet leaders in Florida.
newsitem.headline: Republicans big donors meet leaders in Florida.

text.p: Top financial backers of the Republican Party met party leaders in Florida Thursday with campaign finance reform high on the agenda.

About 200 Republican big spenders, members of the party's exclusive "Team 100," were spending three days golfing and socializing with Republican officials and congressional leaders including House Speaker Newt Gingrich and Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott at a posh Palm Beach resort.

To qualify for membership of the four-year Team 100 group, a contributor must give $100,000 to the party in the first year and $25,000 a year in each of the next three years for a total of $175,000. The group meets twice a year.

Attendees sounded less than enthusiastic about reforming the system of campaign funding, a topic much in the news because of revelations of Democratic Party fundraising from foreigners trying to influence the Clinton administration.

Campaign reform may be good for the nation "but it's not going to happen," former Republican gubernatorial candidate Robin Hayes of North Carolina said. "It would hurt both sides in the way they do things."
President Clinton Tuesday spoke at a fundraising reception for 120 contributors in New York City that raised $1.2 million for Democratic candidates for the Senate.
